 Трудолюбивая  и целеустремленная Аида мечтает поставить на ноги маму  и создать все условия для счастливой жизни своему сыну.
texts.en: Aida was born and grew up in a middle-class family.  Following her father's death, she moved to the Ak-Suu village together with her family, so that they could be closer to relatives.  After completing school, Aida was accepted to the Financial College, but, unfortunately, did not finish it because she got married.  She had a son while she was married, then got divorced, and moved in with her mother.  Today, Aida is the sole provider for her nine-year-old son and paralyzed mother.  In order to provide for her small family, Aida got involved in sales of food products.  Using an initial sum of 10,000 som (KGS), she decided to open a small store on the property of her own house.  Currently, she has 30,000 som (KGS) in her turnover, and she plans to expand her business.  Aida requested a loan in the sum of 30,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company specifically to achieve this goal by expanding her merchandise selection.  Hardworking and goal-oriented Aida dreams of helping her mother get back on her feet and providing all of the conditions for a happy life for her son.

loans.use: to expand her merchandise selection

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is single and has two children with one of them currently in school. 

For the past 10 years, Mary has been working hard to manage her bar, which sells drinks like beer. 

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more beers and soda for resale, and it will help Mary to generate greater profits and buy food to feed her family. 

Mary hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Mary is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mary who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans

loans.use: to buy more beers and soda for resale.

loans.name: Seoun

texts.en:
Seoun, 39, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

Seoun sells rice and vegetables, and her husband is a teacher at a public school. This couple works so hard every day for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Seoun is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more rice to resell. By doing so, she is able to generate more income. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to purchase more rice to resell.

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.en:
Esperanza is 53 years old, married and has 10 children between 11 and 32 years old.

Esperanza and her husband run a fishing business in Talibon, Bohol. Esperanza helps by selling her husband's catch at her town's market. According to Esperanza, they earn about 7,000 PHP per month with their fishing business.

Esperanza has requested a loan to purchase a fishing boat. This will help Esperanza and her husband earn better.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat.

loans.name: Mukaili B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Mukaili B Group in Western Kenya! Florence is the facilitator of the Mukaili B group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Florence takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Florence had a very good maize yield harvesting six bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Florence was only able to harvest two bags of maize on that land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Florence and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Florence will educate her children, ensure food security for her family and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of the Mukaili group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is single and has two children who are currently in school. For the past seven years, Alice has been working hard to manage her brickmaking business, in which she sells bricks and firewood. 

To help expand her business, Alice has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more firewood for resale, and it will help Alice to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Alice hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her supply. 

Alice is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Alice who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to stock more firewood for resale,

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Lutaso B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Lutaso B Group in Western Kenya! Violet is the facilitator of the Lutaso group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Violet takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to feed her family and access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, Violet had a good maize yield harvesting nine bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Violet was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Violet and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Violet will ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Lutaso B group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

She is pictured in the photograph with her group members.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Paul  Ngatu

texts.en:
Paul Ngatu, 33, is married to a tailor and has two children. 

He sells bread to traders, shopkeepers, hotels and butcheries. Besides this business, Paul is a farmer. He is faced with the problem of the high cost of bread when buying it.

He wants a loan of KES 20,000 to buy more loaves of bread. He is a visionary and confident man.

loans.use: To buy more bread.

loans.name: Dovi

texts.fr:
Dovi est une femme  âgé(e) de 63 ans. Elle est veuve et a 05 enfants en charge. L’ainé à 40ans et le dernier a 28ans.
Dovi travaille comme revendeuse de cure dents depuis 1984. Elle vend à ses clients dans un marché de la place.
Dovi a requis son second  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des cures dents. 
Dans les prochaines années, Dovi voudrait accroitre son chiffre d’affaire afin d’acheter plus de marchandises. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit d’assurer le bien être de la famille.
texts.en:
Dovi is a 63-year-old woman. She is a widow and has five children in her care. The oldest is 40 and the youngest is 28.
Dovi has worked as a retailer selling toothpicks since 1984. She sells to her customers at a market in the area.
Dovi has requested her second loan from WAGES in order to buy toothpicks.
In the coming years, Dovi would like to increase her sales in order to buy more merchandise. She says that with the profits, she intends to ensure the well-being of her family.

loans.use: To buy toothpicks.

loans.name: Faridah

texts.en:
Faridah is 32 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. For the past ten years, Faridah has been working hard to manage her stationery shop, which sells paper. 

To help expand her business, Faridah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more paper for resale, and will help Faridah to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Faridah hopes that in the future she will be able to increase capital.

Faridah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Faridah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more paper for resale

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en:
This is Romeo, 50, resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Milagros, a vendor and mother to their five children. Romeo, together with his wife, manage their own household while operating the business. He works hard to provide for their everyday expenses.

Romeo operates a rug-making business. He mainly offers rugs, from round palm-sized ones, to the much larger doormats and other crafts that most rug-makers come up with every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, they are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeep down the highway. His regular customers are neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of Php 3,000 in sales every week.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a loan of Php 23,000. He will be using this loan to buy more raw materials like fabric, thread and other items needed in his business. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. 

Romeo hopes to be able to expand soon and hopes to support his children's schooling up to the college level. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials needed for his business

loans.name: Debra Wachuka

texts.en: Debra Wachuka 72 years old, widowed and has three children. She sells clothes to new and frequent customers in the town of Nakuru. She has been in this business for the last five years and has one employee.The business is faced with the challenge of insufficient capital to allow the purchase of more stock. Debra is requesting a loan of KES 40,000 to buy more clothes as there will be a high demand during December holiday. She describes herself as a determined and hardworking woman.

loans.use: to buy clothes

loans.name: Toch

texts.en:
Toch, 41, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean sites. 

Toch is employed at the factory, and her husband is a motor-taxi driver. This couple works so hard every day for incomes to help cover the family expenses. 

Toch is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a tuk-tuk (a passenger trailer) to expand her husband’s transportation business. By doing so, her family is able to generate more income. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a tuk-tuk to expand her husband's transportation services.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is a single mother of five school-aged children. She owns a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

Salama has operated a fabric retail business for the past five months; in addition she runs a beauty salon. Her potential clients are her neighbours and friends. She faces a major challenge of inadequate capital to run her business. She dreams of expanding her business.

With a loan of KES 15,000, Salama wants to purchases more fabric for resale. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance because of its low loan interest rates.

loans.use: to purchases more fabrics for resale.

loans.name: Mary Nyambura

texts.en: Mary Nyambura, 33, is married and has two children. She has been selling shoes and herbal medicine for the last fifteen years in the town of Nakuru. The business is facing the problem of high competition within the area. Mary is requesting a loan of KES 80,000 to increase her stock of shoes and medicine. In the five years to come, she sees herself as a major supplier of shoes and medicine at fair prices, to promote to a better life of her clients. Mary is innovative, honest, responsible and respectful.

loans.use: to increase stock of shoes and herbal medicine

loans.name: Victor Koome

texts.en: Victor Koome 23, is single with no children. He owns a retail shop which has been his business for the last ten years. His business is located in a good conducive environment. Victor is also a farmer. His business is faced with current inflation of goods. He is requesting a loan of KES 20,000 to add more stock to his retail shop. He is innovative and energetic.

loans.use: to add more stock.

loans.name: Munhdulam

texts.en: Munhdulam is 44 years old and lives with her husband in ger (Mongolian yurt) in the city of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia.Her husband is a welder. She started her garment retail business in 2005 by renting a counter selling boots. Now she sells all kinds of garments. She is well known for her eye for fashion. Now that her business is stable, Munhdulam is planning to start another retail counter in the market. She has already arranged for a counter, however, she is lacking supplies. Munhdulam is a sharp and hardworking woman who is requesting a loan of MNT 2,500,000 to purchase winter garment.

loans.use: to purchase winter garments

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past three years, Rosemary has been working hard to manage her video store, which sells video tapes. 

To help expand her business, Rosemary has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more video CDs and DVDs for resale, and will help Rosemary generate greater profits to buy food for her family. Rosemary hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Rosemary is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rosemary who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more video CDs and DVDS for resale

loans.name: Naomi Waithera

texts.en: Naomi Waithera, 34, is married to a businessman and they have a 12-year-old daughter. Naomi has a grocery shop where she sells vegetables like tomatoes, potatoes, kales, carrots and cabbages. Besides this, she has a restaurant in the city market of Nairobi. Naomi's business is faced with the problem of ongoing construction of the Thika super highway. She is requesting a loan of KES 30,000 to buy tomatoes, cabbages and potatoes. Naomi describes herself as honest and ambitious.

loans.use: to purchase tomatoes, cabbages and potatoes.

loans.name: Akouwa

texts.fr:
Akouwa est une femme âgée de 42 ans. Elle est mariée å un guide touristique. Elle a 3 enfants.  
Akouwa travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2007. Elle vend des articles de quincailleries dans une boutique.
Akouwa a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des articles de quincailleries. 
Elle  prévoit assurer un avenir meilleur à ses enfants.
texts.en:
Akouwa is a 42-year-old woman. She is married to a tour guide. She has three children.
Akouwa has worked as a retailer since 2007. She sells hardware items at a store.
Akouwa has requested her first loan from WAGES in order to buy hardware items.
She intends to ensure a better future for her children.

loans.use: To buy hardware items.

loans.name: Khursheeda's Group

texts.en:
Khursheeda is 33 years old. She is an embroidery and sewing expert and works for her community clients. Due to her good quality work, she receives regular orders every month. Her husband sells fertilizers. His customers include farmers who purchase fertilizers from him to use on their crops.

Khursheeda is the mother of two sons and two daughters. None of them is able to attend school due to the poor financial conditions of Khursheeda and her husband.

She has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her brother who also runs a fertilizer retail business and who is currently facing low stock problems. With the help of a loan he will purchase different brands and variety of fertilizers for his shop to generate more sales and profits. He has been operating this business for many years and Khursheeda is hopeful that a loan will help her brother increase his business profits.

Note: "In the picture, the lady holding a book called Asasah passbook is Khursheeda."

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her business

loans.name: Ma. Delia

texts.en:
51-year-old Ma. Delia buys and sells seashells for a living. She is a married woman with no children yet. Ma. Delia works hard to improve her business and save for the future.

Ma. Delia is requesting a loan to buy more seashells to sell. This is the first time that Ma. Delia has asked for a loan. She said she learned about CEVI through her friends who also availed of its financial services. Ma. Delia is hopeful that this loan will help her have a progressive business.

loans.use: to buy more seashells to sell

loans.name: Allah Rakhi's Group

texts.en:
Allah Rakhi is 45 years old and operates a thread-selling business. She gets thread from used clothes and sells to different thread sellers in the market to earn income for her family. She works very hard to support her husband in putting three meals on the table for her family. 

She is the mother of two sons and a daughter. Her sons work in a factory while her daughter is a seamstress. 

Allah Rakhi has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her thread-selling business. With the loan she will buy used clothes (sweaters) in bulk quantity that will allow her to prepare larger quantities of thread and make more income by selling. 

She has been operating her business for the past five years and is very confident that an investment will be a productive one for her. 

She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 
Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Allah Rakhi.

loans.use: to buy used clothes (sweaters) for her thread-selling business

loans.name: Irene Mumbi

texts.en: Irene Mumbi is 29 years old, married, and has two daughters. She is a tailor. She makes clothes and school uniforms and sells them to schools, both to new and frequent customers. The business faces high demand from her clients. This make it difficult for her to be able to meet her customer's needs, since she has limited materials for making clothes. She wants a loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy more materials and a sewing machine. Irene describes herself as optimistic and confident.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine and materials.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
This is Elena, 42, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Miguelito, a vendor, and mother to their three children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Elena operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers and sell them with a little profit. Her products are children’s clothes, ready-to-wear and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy from her due to her low selling prices and the many options she offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 900 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan for 50,000 PHP. She will be utilizing the loan to buy ready-to-wear products and merchandise items to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Elena hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all of her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks of merchandise items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Eunice Nyokabi

texts.en: Eunice Nyokabi is 38 years old, married to a businessman, and has two children. She has been a dressmaker for the last three months and sells the clothes she makes to frequent customers and schools. She wants a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy a sewing machine and add more materials. Eunice is organized, neat, and loves what she does.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine and add materials to her stock.

loans.name: Jirani Mwema Wg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Jirani Mwema WG Group in Western Kenya! Alice is the facilitator of the group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Alice takes care of seven children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Alice had an excellent maize yield harvesting 25 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Alice was only able to harvest 15 bags of maize on one acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Alice and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. 

With the income from maize sales, Alice will educate her children and ensure food security for her family. 

In 2012, the members of Jirani Mwema WG group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

She is pictured in the photograph with her group members.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase stock of flour, milk and beans.

loans.name: Benon

texts.en:
Benon is 40 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has four children, 3 of whom are currently in school. For the past two years Benon has been working hard to manage his bar, which sells drinks like beer. 

To help expand his business, Benon has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more beers and soda for resale, and will help Benon to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Benon hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his business more. 

Benon is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Benon who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more beers and soda for resale,

loans.name: Romualdo

texts.en:
Romualdo is 28 years old, married, and happy to have one kid. Romualdo’s wife has been an overseas Filipino worker for almost three years. Romualdo acts as a father and mother as well in the absence of his wife.

Romualdo is a farmer. He plants rice and harvests after four months of planting. He has been managing his farming business for five years. Romualdo doesn’t want only to rely on his wife's remittances to be able to finance their farm needs. He knows how difficult it is to be far from family, which is why he is working hard and strives to help his wife even in a simple way.

Romualdo is requesting a loan of 50,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy seeds of rice, fertilizers and herbicides to be used in farming. He considers that the loan will be a big help for him to help his wife in providing for his own farm needs.

loans.use: to buy seeds of rice, fertilizers and herbicides to be used in farming.

loans.name: Liana

texts.en:
Liana is 37 years old. She is not married and lives with her brother and sister in law.

Liana has a higher education and for more than 13 years she worked in State Structure, but since the salary was not high Liana decided to run her own business.  

Since 2004 Liana has been engaged in a toys-trading business. Liana imports toys from United Arab Emirates and other countries and resells them in her rented place in one of Yerevan’s subways. Her brother helps Liana in her trading. Liana likes her business and does her work with great pleasure. 

What is important in Liana’s business? Liana puts emphasis on ecologically-clean produced toys and she says that her costumers are “children” from new born ages to adult because all of us are children during our whole life.   

Liana needs a loan for 1,000,000 Armenian drams (AMD) to add to her toys assortments for Christmas and New Year sales.

loans.use: to add toy assortments for Christmas and New Year sales

loans.name: Tonggara Grace Group

texts.en: Katarina is 35 years old and married with one child. She is pictured standing in the middle of the photo wearing a red shirt. She has been selling drinks and phone minute refills for two years in front of her house. The sales are going well and she enjoys running the kiosk because it has taught her a lot about business. She is still trying learn the best way to grow her business and increase her income. She is thinking about moving to a better location in the future. Her husband is an electrician, and together they have enough income to support the daily needs of the family and the preschool fees for their child. This is her first loan with VisionFund Indonesia and she plans to use it to buy more drinks and mobile phone minute refills to sell and hopefully help grow her business.

loans.use: to pay for more drinks and mobile phone minute refills to sell in her kiosk.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is 55, married, and has four adult children. They live happily in a village and farm for a living. They own and manage 2 hectares of farmland and plant corn and vegetables for sale. Although corn farming is difficult to manage, through patience and hard work they are able to have a plentiful harvest. They have aimed to expand their corn plantation to increase their yields and income to support the education of their youngest children who are now in college.

Due to financial constraints, Evangeline is asking for additional capital of 30,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy corn seeds, fertilizers, pesticides and pay the labor cost required for planting corn. She believes that this loan will help them to work out their plan and they are hoping that they will be having a plentiful harvest this coming harvest season.

loans.use: to buy corn seeds, fertilizers, pesticides and the pay labor cost required for planting corn.

loans.name: Jirani Mwema B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Jirani Mwema B Group in Western Kenya! Judith is the facilitator of the group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Judith takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Judith had a very good maize yield harvesting 10 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Judith was only able to harvest two bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Judith and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Judith will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Jirani Mwema group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

She is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en:
Myagmarsuren is 38 years old and lives with her husband and four kids in a ger, a Mongolian felt tent, in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her husband and elder child work in the same company, her middle child is a college student, and the youngest two are in school. In 2007, Myagmarsuren started a home-product trading business in a rural area. She decided to move to the city for sake of her children's education and has arranged for someone to help run her business. Myagmarsuren is a sharp and hardworking woman who says “I have seen other people who sell products and it is pretty much the same products that I sold in the past so I am not that worried about my business.” 

Myagmarsuren is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more goods for her business.

loans.use: to purchase goods

loans.name: Filipina

texts.en:
This is Filipina. She is 46 and a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Eduardo, a vendor, and mother to four children. She, together with her husband, manages her own household while operating her business. Filipina is a fish vendor who works hard to continually provide income for her family’s everyday expenses. She buys different kinds of fish at wholesale prices and sells them by the kilo. Many patrons prefer her products, since she buys fish at the local fish port early in the morning and her customers are assured of its freshness and cleanliness. Her store is located in a temporary fish market and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. Filipina earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP in sales every day.

Filipina is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan to help continue her business. She will use her loan to buy more fish to sell every day and she expects a boost in her business income as she expands. Filipina dreams of giving all of her children a good and high quality education through her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members each week to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 


* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. Fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is married and has four children who are all currently in school. For the past seven years, Ruth has been working hard to manage her small shop where she sells hardware. 

To help expand her business, Ruth has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda to purchase supplies and materials. Her loan will help her generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Ruth hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Ruth is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Ruth, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase hardware and supplies

loans.name: Emilie

texts.en:
Emilie is 37 years old and married with three children, two of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. For the past 13 years, Emilie has run a spice-selling business in the Philippines. 

Emile is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more spices to sell in her stall. In the future, she would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy spices to sell in her stall

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is a married man with four school-going children. His wife is a farmer who contributes to the provision of the family’s basic needs. Samson lives in a rental house without electricity or running water and his greatest monthly expense is food for his family. For the last four years, he has operated an agro-vet supply business and his clients are local area farmers. Samson’s major business challenge is seasonality. He decided to join Yehu Microfinance because it provides financial services to low income earners.
 
Samson is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES to purchase more fertilizer and pesticide to sell. In the future, he dreams of expanding his business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pesticide to sell

loans.name: Aynur

texts.ru:
Айнур  родилась и выросла в Чуйской области, замужем, мать двух  дочерей - студенток.  Супруг Зумрат работает торговым представителем российской фирмы. 
10 лет назад Айнур начала заниматься животноводством. Стартовав с суммой в 30,000  сом (KGS), Айнур, благодаря своему упорству и труду, смогла развить хозяйство с ежемесячной прибылью около 10,000 сом (KGS).  На данный момент в собственности Айнур имеется две головы нетели и три дойные коровы, продажа удоя местному молокоперерабатывающему комбинату позволяет  зарабатывать около 10,000 сом в месяц. В целях дальнейшего увеличения поголовья скота, Айнур обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом на покупку дойных коров.  В будущем, Айнур планирует основать большое и стабильное хозяйство.
texts.en: Aynur was born and grew up in the Chuysk region.  She is married and is a mother of two daughters, both of whom are students.  Aynur's husband, Zumrat, works as a sales representative of a Russian firm.  Aynur got involved in animal husbandry ten years ago with an initial sum of 30,000 som (KGS).  Thanks to her persistence and hard work, Aynur was able to grow her business to have a monthly profit of about 10,000 som (KGS).  She currently has two heads of heifers and three dairy cows.  Sales of milk to the local milk processing plant allows her to earn about 10,000 som per month.  In order to further increase her livestock headcount, Aynur requested a loan in the sum of 100,000 som from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to buy dairy cows.  In the future, Aynur plans to establish a large and stable business.

loans.use: to purchase dairy cows

loans.name: Peter Mathea

texts.en: Peter Mathea is 50 years old, married, and has four children. He has been making and repairing shoes for the last 21 years. He sells the shoes he makes to new and frequent customers. His business faces challenges having to do with labor and materials. Peter wants a loan of KES 20,000 to buy leather and employ one person. He describes himself as honest and experienced.

loans.use: to purchase leather.

loans.name: Felecidad

texts.en:
Felecidad is married and works hard to support her family. For the past four years, she has run a food production business in the Philippines.

Felecidad is requesting a 13,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more ingredients and utensils for her business. In the future, she would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients and utensils

loans.name: Tembelesia A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Tembelesia A Group in Western Kenya! Jackline is the facilitator of the Tembelesia A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Jackline takes care of one child at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Jackline had a very good maize yield harvesting eight bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jackline was only able to harvest two bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jackline and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Jackline will educate her children, ensure food security for her family, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Tembelesia A group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Colleta  Shirwatso

texts.en:
Colleta Shirwatso is 35 years old and has four children. She is married to a businessman. For the past four years, she has run a hair salon and she has one employee. Colleta is also a farmer and her major business challenge is the poor road network. She describes herself as a hardworking and visionary woman.

Colleta is requesting a 20,000 KES loan to buy hair dryers. In the future, she sees herself running a cosmetic shop and employing more workers.

loans.use: to buy hair dryers

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 42 years old and lives in the town of Kititale in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is single and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past 18 years, Aisha has been working hard to manage her small shop where she sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 3,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda to buy more clothes for resale. Her loan will help Aisha generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. She hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house of her own. 

Aisha is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Aisha, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen is 36 years old. Her husband is 27 years old and works as a computer operator. The couple has a three-year-old son who is not yet in school. Yasmeen helps support her family by doing sewing and embroidery. She is very good at her work and her clothing is in high demand among her clients in the community.

Yasmeen is requesting a loan from the KIVA partner Asasah to buy a new sewing machine to help her finish client orders on time and earn more income. She has a good deal of experience and is confident that buying a new sewing machine will allow her to successfully upgrade her business.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to harvest her rice

loans.name: Iddah Apondi

texts.en: Iddah Apondi is 42 years old, married to a teacher, and has six children. She has been selling poultry and vegetables for the last 20 years to both new and frequent customers. Iddah's business is faced with challenges such as poultry dying before maturity and eggs breaking. She wants a  loan of KES 40,000 to buy more layers and boilers (which are types of chickens). In the next five years, she sees herself becoming the major supplier in Kakamega town, which is a competitive and busy place. Iddah is ambitious, polite, and patient.

loans.use: to buy more layers and broilers.

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie works hard to support her family. Julie is married and has a rice retailing business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 4 years now, and also earns additional income from manicure/pedicure services.

Julie requested an 11,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more stocks of rice to sell.

In the future, Julie would like to save enough money so she can continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of rice to sell

loans.name: Munhtuya

texts.en:
Munhtuya is 33 years old and lives with her husband and twin sons in a ger (Mongolian yurt), in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her husband works in a leather factory and her sons study in school. 

Munhtuya started her grocery retail business in 2008 by renting a counter in the market. Now that major market is opening in a new area, and Munhtuya rented a counter there. Therefore, she needs a supply to run the place. She is requesting 3,000,000 MNT to buy more grocery products.

Munhtuya is a sharp and diligent woman who says "The new market is in highly crowded place therefore I believe it will pay off."

loans.use: to buy more grocery products

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is a 33-year-old married woman. She describes herself to be a God-fearing woman. She has been selling clothes that is jackets and jumpers for last 10 years. Her business is located in a shopping centre and she has both repeat and new customers. In addition, she also sells poultry. She describes her biggest business challenge to be climate change. She will use the 50,000 KES loan to buy more jackets and sweaters. Christine's goal and dream is to venture into new business of poultry in the next five years.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Grecilda

texts.en: Twenty-two-year-old Grecilda is a married woman with 3 children. She is engaged in farming. Grecilda primarily grows rice crops to sell. She also grows banana plants. Grecilda has been in this kind of business for 3 years. She is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers and rice seeds. She hopes to have a stable income that will help her achieve her goals, like send her children to college and build a new house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and rice seeds

loans.name: Mastula

texts.en:
Mastula is 48 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala South region of Uganda. She is widowed and has 2 children. For the past 3 years, Mastula has been working hard to manage her salon, which does hairdressing for local women. 

To help expand her business, Mastula has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase the equipment needed to do special braids, and will help Mastula to generate greater profits and buy food to feed her family. Mastula hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her savings. 

Mastula is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Mastula, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase the equipment needed to do special braids

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dryer and a piece of hair-cutting equipment.

loans.name: Ruth Muthoni

texts.en:
Ruth, a 42 year old married woman, has three children ranging in age from 4 to 15 years. Describing herself as ambitious, honest and faithful, Ruth has been renting out houses for 10 years. Her business is located in a shopping centre in the town of Nakuru, and she has many clients, her biggest business challenge being those who don't make their payments.

Ruth will use the Kes 20,000 loan to renovate and improve the rental houses. Her business goal is to add more rental houses within the next five years.

loans.use: to improve and renovate her rental facilities.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a single mother. She has one child, who is in school. She lives in her family’s house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

Mwanakombo has operated as a tailor for the past three years; her potential clients are local women. She faces a major challenge of inadequate capital to expand her business. She dreams of expanding her business.

With her loan of KES 20,000 she wants to purchase more fabrics and also buy some vegetables for her new grocery business. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance because of its quality financial services.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics and to buy vegetables for her new grocery business.

loans.name: Leah Kakai

texts.en: Leah is a 24-year-old married woman. She has a child who is three years old. She describes herself as ambitious. She operates a grocery store where she sells kale, tomatoes, onions, cabbages, and other vegetables. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a shopping center in Nakuru. She describes her biggest business challenge as inadequate capital. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to increase her stock of vegetables. Her goal is to grow her store into a wholesale business within five years. She hopes that, in the future, she will own a stall where she will be running her business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for her grocery store.

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
This is Nena, 33, a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Angel, her business partner and father to her three children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Nena operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals in the evenings, when all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a typical family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to use cooking gas and food to prepare meals for one or two people when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP1000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP35,000 loan. She will utilize the loan to buy greater quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Nena dreams that she will be able to give her all of her children a good and high-quality education through her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members every week to share stories of her work.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products needed for her food business.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is 41 years old and married with four children.

Regina works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy more goods like snack foods, detergents, and other groceries.

Regina has borrowed and repaid 20 loans from NWTF prior to this loan. She has been running the general store for 12 years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

Regina aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more goods like snack foods, detergents, and other groceries.

loans.name: Odonchimeg

texts.en: Odonchimeg is 41 years old and lives with her husband and two kids in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in the city of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband is a chauffeur and her two kids are in school. She started her grocery retail business earlier this year, and it is going so well that she decided to rent another counter in another market. She has already made arrangements for the new counter; however, she is lacking supplies to run the place. Therefore, she is requesting 1,000,000 MNT to buy more grocery products. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who says, "My children are growing so fast, and I have to work hard in order to support them and get them to college. I don't want to live like I did."

loans.use: To buy more grocery products.

loans.name: Divina

texts.en: Divina, a 39-year-old married mother of three,  earns a living by pig-fattening in the Philippines.  She has been in business for 12 years and earns additional income from farming rice. Divina is borrowing PHP 12000 through NWTF to buy additional piglets, feeds and vitamins for her business. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets, feeds and vitamins.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a small entrepreneur who has been selling beauty products such as AVON cosmetics for more than five years now. With the minimal profits earned from the business she is able to provide daily allowances of her children.

Elizabeth, 53, is requesting a loan of P20,000 to buy more products to offer such as perfumes, lipsticks, makeup, powder and intimate apparel. She wants to increase her product offerings to make her business more profitable.

In the future, Elizabeth would like to see all her children earn degrees and someday help to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy more products to offer such as perfumes, lipsticks, makeup, powder and intimate apparel.

loans.name: Abelardo

texts.en:
Abelardo is a 44-year-old farmer, married to a housekeeper, and blessed with four children. Two of his children already work, while the other two are still studying. Giving the best quality of life and enabling his children to complete their education are his priorities. He believes that education is the key to success, and he is doing everything possible to ensure that they become professionals someday.

Abelardo, who has been a rice farmer for 25 years, is now requesting a loan of P45,000 to buy seeds of rice to grow and fertilizers for maintenance.

loans.use: to buy seeds of rice to grow and fertilizers for maintenance.

loans.name: Arlita

texts.en:
This is Arlita, 50, a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Clark, 37, a vendor. She is the mother of four children. Three of her children are married, and her youngest is in high school. She and her husband keep themselves busy in their business to meet their daily expenses. 

Arlita is a fruit vendor. She sells lakatans (a variety of banana that is in demand in the Philippines) in the market. She buys bananas direct from the port area, and all of the bananas that she sells come from Mindanao. She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will utilize the loan to buy more lakatan bananas since the demand is quite high nowadays, especially in hotels, restaurants, and canteens. 

Arlita hopes that her business will last longer and continuously help to sustain their needs. She wishes for good health for all of the members of her family. She hopes that her youngest will be able to finish her studies. She is active in attending the weekly fellowship* as it helps her to have time to share God’s kindness to her. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more fruit for her business.

loans.name: Julito

texts.en:
Julito is 34 years old and married. He has 3 children aged 10, 7, and 1. Julito is a seaweed farmer from Talibon, Bohol. He has been engaged in this kind of business for 7 years. Julito earns 15000 PHP per month from seaweed farming. 

Julito has requested a loan to purchase seaweed seedlings, straw, wooden pegs, and other materials. Julito hopes for his business to grow.

loans.use: to purchase seaweed seedlings, straw, wooden pegs, and other materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fabrics and service her sewing machine.

loans.name: Modesto

texts.en:
As a responsible father, Modesto aims to uplift his family's standard of living and give them a better life. He is 29 and has one infant child. He owns and manages a corn farming business in their village to generate income. He also operates motorcycle transport and hog-raising businesses to earn additional income. He plans to expand his corn plantation to increase his production in the coming harvest season.

He is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides for his corn farming business. He mentioned that he can work out his plan to make a lot of improvements in the business with this additional capital. He hopes that his patience and hard work will bear a fruitful harvest in the coming season.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides for his corn farming business.

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en: Tungalag is 45 years old and lives with her husband and two kids in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in the city of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband works in a factory, her elder son is a cab driver, and her younger son is a student. She started her business in 2002 by sewing at home. She specializes in curtains and toddler garments. Now that she has been in business for quite a long while, demand for her products is increasing. Therefore, she plans to rent a workshop and buy some equipment. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who says, "I always try out new designs for my products, and my customers like it very much. My products sell almost instantly." She is requesting 2,500,000 MNT to buy sewing equipment.

loans.use: To buy sewing equipment.

loans.name: Lara Jane

texts.en:
Lara Jane is 26 years old and has two children. She is married and has one child who is in school.

Lara Jane is in the agriculture business, buying and selling livestock in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 19500 loan through NWTF to buy additional livestock to sell.

Lara Jane has been buying and selling livestock for 10 years now. She has previously borrowed nine times from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Lara Jane would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional livestock to sell

loans.name: Mukewa A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Mukewa A SHG Group in Western Kenya! Alice is the facilitator of the Mukewa A SHG group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Alice takes care of seven children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Alice had an excellent maize yield harvesting 20 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Alice was only able to harvest five bags of maize on one acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Alice and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Alice will educate her children, ensure food security for her family, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Mukewa A SHG group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Shazia's Group

texts.en:
Shazia is a seamstress who sews clothes for her neighbors and clients. She is a very good and skillful worker, and she receives a good number of orders every month. Shazia is the mother of three sons and a daughter. All of them are studying, except the third one who didn’t show an interest in education and remains illiterate

Her husband operates a shop in the market where he sells cigarettes and betel leaves. He also sells cold drinks to his customers. Shazia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to further expand her husband’s business. With the loan, he will put more brands of cigarettes in his shop as well as betel leaves and cold drinks to increase his sales and profits. He has been operating his business for the past six years, and Shazia is hopeful that an investment will help him to increase his profits. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Shazia.

loans.use: To buy cigarettes, betel leaves, and cold drinks to sell.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 27 years old. He is a married father of one child, aged 2 months. He lives in his own house in Hoima, Uganda. He is the only income earner in the family, and hence the responsibility of providing for the family rests on him. 

For the past three years he has been operating a produce business, which he started with 30,000 shillings in capital. Now he has 1,000,000 shillings in capital. He faces challenges of poor roads and inadequate capital. John needs a loan to buy rice, groundnuts, and sorghum to sell. He hopes to move his business to Hoima Town in the near future.

loans.use: to buy rice, groundnuts, and sorghum to sell.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kitintale in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past two years, Robert has been working hard to manage his small shop, which sells electronics. 

To help expand his business, Robert has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more electronic supplies for resale, and it will help Robert to generate greater profits and buy food to feed his family. He hopes that in the future he will be able to build a house of his own. 

Robert is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Robert who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more electronic supplies for resale.

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn is 42 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Marlyn is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been raising pigs for 10 years and also earns additional income from a sari-sari store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business in order to to secure her family's future.

loans.use: To purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Tserendejid

texts.en: Tserendejid is 47 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband is an electrician and her daughter is a clerk. Tserendejid started her grocery retail business in 2008 by renting a counter in the market. Lately, her business is slowing down due to the market environment. Therefore, she decided to move her business to another market. Her new counter is big; therefore her old products are not quite enough to run a business. Tserendejid is a sharp and hardworking woman who is requesting 1,700,000 MNT to purchase products to sell.

loans.use: to purchase products to sell.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a married woman with five schoolgoing children. Her husband, who is employed, also contributes to providing the family's basic needs. She owns a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

Rehema has operated a tailoring and cloth-selling business for the past 15 years; her potential clients are the local area residents. She faces a major challenge of inadequate funds to run her business. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the 20,000 KES, Rehema wants to purchase more fabrics and cloths for her business. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance to access funds to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fabrics and cloths for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay workers to dig and to buy pesticides.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman with three schoolgoing children. Her husband, who is employed, also contributes to providing the family's basic needs. She owns a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

Mariam has operated a retail shop for the past 10 years; her potential clients are her neighbors. She faces a major lack of capital to expand her business. She dreams of expanding her business to a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase more stock of rice, maize flour, wheat flour and cooking oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance to access funds to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of rice, maize flour, wheat flour and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent is married and has eight children. He lives in Katikara, Uganda. He has a produce business, which he has been operating for three years. He started as a farmer and then saved to start his produce business. He faces business challenges, including customers' late payments and seasonal variations. 

Innocent's family goal is to educate his children and build a permanent house for his family. He hopes to expand his business to new markets. Innocent intends to buy rice and African groundnuts with the loan.

loans.use: to purchase rice and African groundnuts.

loans.name: Erdenegerel

texts.en: Erdenegerel is 53 years old and lives with her daughter in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her daughter is employed. She started her grocery retail business in 1997 with a small shop. Now she has decided to rent a counter in the market, which is a big step for her. She is a hardworking and diligent woman who says, "Now that my daughter is old enough, it is time to concentrate on my business." She is requesting 1,500,000 MNT to buy supplies.

loans.use: to buy supplies.

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en:
Romeo is a father who raised his family in a village. He is 48 years old and has three school-age children. He has been a farmer for almost 28 years. He usually plants corn and vegetables and raises hogs to sell. His ambition in life is to improve the status of living for his family and to give his children the best education they need. Sometimes, there are problems and difficulties they encounter, but through their strong determination, they can survive. 

Romeo aims to cultivate a 2 hectares of farm land to plant more corn. Due to inadequate capital, he requires an additional PHP30,000 to buy fertilizers, pesticides, corn seeds and to pay for the labor costs required to plant corn. He believes that this loan will help him to make an improvement in his business. He is hoping that he will be having a plentiful harvest to support the education of their children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, pesticides, corn seeds and labor cost required in planting corn.

loans.name: Enkhbat

texts.en:
Enkhbat now needs some money to expand his workshop and renovate some of his service equipment. These changes are beneficial to his business future. 

The loan Enkhbat is taking will be used to purchase new equipment for his auto service and some building materials to make workshop renovations.

loans.use: to purchase the new equipment for his auto service and some building materials to make workshop renovations.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a responsible father who's priority in life is to uplift his family's living conditions, especially to finance the schooling of his children. According to him, education is the only legacy he could pass on to his children because his family is less fortunate. 

George is 33 years old, married to a housewife and they were blessed with three children. George now asks for a loan of PHP29,000 to pay for a license and to buy side mirrors for his motorcycle. He believes that, through the help of this loan, he can improve his services and continously operate his business. 

George hopes to make her business more profitable despite difficulties he encounters in providing motorcycle services to the people in their village.

loans.use: to pay for his license and to buy side mirrors for his motorcycle.

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is a married man with one child who is still too young for school. His wife is a businesswoman who contributes to providing basic needs for his family. He lives in a rental house with neither electricity, nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for his family.

Fred has operated as a ‘Jua Kali’ artisan for the past five years; his potential clients are his neighbors and friends. He faces a major challenge of raising prices of raw materials. He dreams of expanding his business.

With the KES 10,000 he wants to purchase raw materials like iron and also to build premises for his business. He decided to join Yehu Microfinance to access financial aid to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials like iron and also to build premises for his business.

loans.name: Bricelda

texts.en:
Bricelda is 31 years old and is a married woman. She has 2 children. She has been a seaweed farmer for 3 years. Bricelda earns 6000 PHP per month from seaweed farming. Bricelda also makes food items like "pilipit" (crunchy, sweet bread) to sell to her community.

Bricelda has requested a loan to purchase straw, wooden pegs and other materials for seaweed farming. Bricelda hopes for her business to improve. She also hopes to save for her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase straw, wooden pegs and other materials for seaweed farming.

loans.name: Azjargal

texts.en: Mr. Azjargal is 26 years old and lives with his wife in Kherlen, a boundary town of western Mongolia. He works as a watchman in a private company and his monthly salary is not enough for his family expenses currently. His family lives in a house that was built over 25 years ago. In the past several years, his house has become very old and damaged. His house becomes especially cold during the wintertime due to the fact that the walls are without insulation. Also, he needs to renovate his home furniture after the adjustment to the house. Therefore, the loan he is taking will be dedicated to purchasing the building materials to insulate the walls and purchase some new Western furniture for his rooms.

loans.use: To insulate the walls and purchase some new Western furniture for his rooms.

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en:
Hadijah is married with four children. For five years, she has been owning a clothing business. However, she faces a challenge of the business being seasonal. Her personal goal is to build a permanent house for her family and educate her children.

She hopes to expand her business to new markets. Hadijah needs a loan to stock clothes to sell in order to take advantage of the Christmas season.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Tsuma

texts.en:
Tsuma is a married man with six school-going children. His wife is a businesswoman who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. He lives in a rental house with neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for his family. 

Tsuma has operated a vegetable grocery for the past three years; his potential clients are the local area residents. He faces a major challenge of inadequate capital to expand his business. He aspires to become a vegetable supplier in his town.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, he wants to purchase vegetables like onions, tomatoes and others for resale. He decided to join Yehu Microfinance because it helps low-income earners by giving them loans to expand their business.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables like onions, tomatoes and others for resale.

loans.name: Mayrambu

texts.ru: Майрамбу 58 лет, замужем.  Основная деятельность семьи Майрамбу – это откорм и перепродажа скота и полеводство.  Начатое еще в 1972 году,  в  период Советского Союза со стартовой суммой в 120 советских рублей хозяйство сегодня приносит около 10,000 сом (KGS) в месяц.   В данный момент, семья Майрамбу обрабатывает 1,74 га орошаемой земли , где выращивают картофель и многолетние травы. В целях дальнейшего увеличения поголовья скота, Майрамбу обратилась в компанию «Бай  Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 40,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дополнительного скота. Это позволит ей увеличить своей хозяйство и приумножить поголовье скота, сделав, таким образом по ее мнению, наилучшее капиталовложение.
texts.en: Mayrambu is 58 years old and married.  Her family's primary business is fattening up and reselling livestock and farming.  Started in 1972, during the period of the Soviet Union, and with an initial sum of 120 Soviet rubles, this business currently yields about 10,000 so (KGS) per month.  At the present time, Mayrambu's family treats 1.74 hectares of irrigated land, where they grow potatoes and multi-year herbs.  In order to further increase livestock headcount, Mayrambu requested a loan in the sum of 40,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to purchase additional livestock.  This will help her expand her business and increase livestock headcount and, thus, in her opinion, make a good capital investment.

loans.use: to purchase additional livestock

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 34-year-old single mother of four children. She has been running a clothing and textile business for 6 years now. She faces a challenge of seasonal weather changes, which makes access to some markets difficult especially during the rainy season. Beatrice needs the loan to purchase clothes to sell. 

In the future, Beatrice wishes to educate her children and build a house for her family. She wants to expand her business to new markets in the future and she is requesting a loan to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: to purchase clothes to sell.

loans.name: Ndolele S.h.g  A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Ndolele S.H.G. A Group in Western Kenya! Irene is the facilitator of Ndolele S.H.G. A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Irene takes care of seven children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Irene had an excellent maize yield harvesting 22 bags on two acres of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Irene was only able to harvest six bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Irene and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Irene will educate her children, ensure food security for her family, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Ndolele S.H.G. A group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

In the picture the person standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is a hard working single mother of 3 children aged 15 to 2 years old living in Hioma, Uganda. She has a dependent and she is the only source of income in the family. She lives in a rented house and her dream is to build a permanent house for residence.

Eva owns a fresh food business and has been running it for 10 years now. She has no hardships and she hopes to expand her business. Eva is in need of a loan to purchase fresh food to sell.

loans.use: to buy fresh food.

loans.name: Siring

texts.fr: L'emprunteuse est une femme mariée qui vit avec son marie et ses trois enfants.Elle exerce un commerce de produits ménagers notamment de balaies qu'elle achète en gros et les revend en détails.Son commerce génère des revenus assez consistants qui lui permettent de se prendre en charge et de participer à l'entretien de sa famille. Elle sollicite un prêt de 300000f pour acheter des balaies, de l'huile de palm et des produits ménagers divers.Son ambition est de construire une cantine devant son domicile et de vendre ses produits en gros aux détaillants des quartiers de sa localité.
texts.en:
Siring is a married woman who lives with her husband and her three children. She runs a business selling home products, such as brooms, which she buys wholesale and then retail.

Her business provides her with a fairly consistent income, which enables her to provide for herself and take part in supporting her family.

She's seeking a loan of XOF 300'000 in order to buy brooms, palm oil, and various other home products.

Her ambition is to open a small shop in front of her home to wholesale her products to the retailers of the neighborhoods of her town.

loans.use: to buy brooms, palm oil, and various other home products

loans.name: Rehana Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Rehana Kosar is married and has five children. Her first two sons are auto mechanics by profession. Her other two sons are free and don’t do anything while her daughter has passed the 5th grade and now runs a sewing business from her home to supplement the income of her family. Her husband is also an auto mechanic.  

Rehana herself is a very hard working woman. She operates a business selling toys. She sells plastic and battery-operated toys to her customers and to toy shops for profit. She does this work to support her family financially.
 
Rehana has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner Asasah for the expansion of her business selling toys. With the loan, she will buy the latest variety of toys in bulk to be able to increase sales and profits. She is hopeful that her business will bring better profits to her after the loan investment.

loans.use: to buy the latest variety of toys to sell.

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
Criselda is 44 years old and is married with five children. Her husband is a farmer and is her partner in times of joy, sadness, and difficulties. With their status of living, Criselda and her husband find it difficult to provide for the needs of educating their children. But, the couple don’t want to lose the hope that they can overcome the difficulties they have encountered.

Criselda runs their rice farming business. She and her husband are working together to ensure that their crops are in good condition and can get a high yield. Criselda is not able to finance both the daily allowances of her children and the needs of her farm. That’s why she prefers to ask for a loan of 40,000 PHP to buy seeds of rice, fertilizers, herbicides, and insecticides for farming. She hopes to take advantage of the loan that would really be a great help for her family.

loans.use: to buy seeds of rice, fertilizers, herbicides, and insecticides for farming.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is a young father of 28 years old. He has two infant children. Due to a lack of job opportunities, he engages in maize farming and sells vegetables to generate income. Sometimes they experience financial difficulty, but through the support of their parents they can survive. He aims to improve the business to increase their income, to satisfy their needs and save for the future of their children. They want them to become professionals in the future so that they will not be like him, with no stable job.

Despite the hardships of farming, Henry aims to expand his maize plantation to have a plentiful harvest. He is asking for a loan of P25,000 to buy maize seeds, fertilizers, insecticides, and to pay the labour costs needed for planting maize. He mentioned that this loan will be a great help to him to improve his maize plantation. He is hoping that someday, he will become financially stable and support his own family.

loans.use: to buy maize seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and to pay labor costs required in planting maize

loans.name: Akbari's Group

texts.en:
Akbari is 41 years old and spends her time staying at home and doing her household responsibilities. Her husband sells buffaloes and milk to his community clients for profit. Akbari provides full support to her husband and takes care of the cattle by keeping their living place clean and giving them good quality food. She has given birth to 6 children. Her eldest son is 15 years old and helps his father to operate his business.

Akbari has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy another buffalo, which he will sell for profit. He is operating his business for the past many years and Akbari is confident that an investment will bring more profits to him and will improve the living conditions of her family. 

Note: "In the picture, the lady holding the passbook called Asasah passbook is Akbari".

loans.use: to buy a buffalo for her livestock business.

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en:
Sauda is applying for another loan to start a new retail shop business. She will use this 40,000 Kes loan to purchase stocks of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and soap for resale. In the future, Sauda aspires to continue improving her businesses. 

Since taking her last Kiva loan, Sauda has greatly improved her family’s standard of living. She hopes to continue accessing the financial services offered by Yehu and Kiva lenders and thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase stocks of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and soap for resale.

loans.name: Anar

texts.ru: Anar jive v Baku regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. On jenat i imeyet dvux prekasnix detey , odin ix kotorix xodit v shkolu. Anar 33 qoda.
